column1: Clearwater is a city located in Pinellas County
column3: United States
column4: northwest of Tampa and St. Petersburg. To the west of Clearwater lies the Gulf of Mexico and to the southeast lies Tampa Bay. As of the 2010 census
column5: the city had a population of 107
column6: 685. Clearwater is the county seat of Pinellas County and is the smallest of the three principal cities in the Tampa–St. Petersburg–Clearwater metropolitan area
column7: most commonly referred to as the Tampa Bay Area.

column1: Cleveland Street is one of the city's historic avenues
column2: and the city includes Spectrum Field and Coachman Park. The city is separated by the Intracoastal Waterway from Clearwater Beach.

column1: Clearwater is the home of Clearwater Marine Aquarium
column2: where bottlenose dolphins Winter and Hope live.

column1: The global headquarters of the Church of Scientology is located in Clearwater.
Present-day Clearwater was originally the home of the Tocobaga people. Around 1835
column2: the United States Army began construction of Fort Harrison
column3: named after William Henry Harrison
column4: as an outpost during the Seminole Wars. The fort was located on a bluff overlooking Clearwater Harbor
column5: which later became part of an early 20th-century residential development called Harbor Oaks. University of South Florida archaeologists excavated the site in 1962 after Mark Wyllie discovered an underground ammunition bunker while planting a tree in his yard.The area's population grew after the Federal Armed Occupation Act of 1842 offered 160 acres (0.65 km2) to anyone who would bear arms and cultivate the land. Early settlers included the Stevens
column8: who claimed and farmed large tracts of land. Prior to 1906
column9: the area was known as Clear Water Harbor. The name "Clear Water" is thought to have come from a fresh water spring flowing from near where the City Hall building is located today. There were many other freshwater springs that dotted the bluff
column10: many in the bay or harbor itself.

column2: the first road joining Clearwater and Tampa was built in 1849
column3: which dramatically reduced the prior day-long commute between the cities.

column2: Union gunboats repeatedly raided the community's supplies
column3: as most of the able-bodied men were away fighting for the Confederate Army. The town began developing in the late nineteenth century
column4: prompted by Peter Demens' completion of the first passenger railroad line into the city in 1888. Clearwater was incorporated in 1891
column5: with James E. Crane becoming the first mayor. The area's popularity as a vacation destination grew after railroad magnate Henry B. Plant built a sprawling Victorian resort hotel named Belleview Biltmore just south of Clearwater in 1897.

column2: Clearwater's population had grown to around 400

column11: and was designated the county seat for Pinellas County
column12: which broke from Hillsborough County in 1912. In 1915
column13: a bridge was built across Clearwater Harbor
column14: joining the city with Clearwater Beach to the west. Clearwater Beach
column15: although located on a separate barrier island
column16: belongs to the city of Clearwater and fronts the Gulf of Mexico. A new
column17: much higher bridge now arcs over the bay
column18: replacing the former drawbridge; the connecting road is part of State Road 60 and is called Clearwater Memorial Causeway.

column2: Clearwater became a major training base for US troops destined for Europe and the Pacific. Virtually every hotel in the area
column3: including the Belleview Biltmore and the Fort Harrison Hotel
column4: was used as a barracks for new recruits. Vehicle traffic was regularly stopped for companies of soldiers marching through downtown
column5: and nighttime blackouts to confuse potential enemy bombers were common practice. The remote and isolated Dan's Island
column7: was used as a target by U.S. Army Air Corps fighter-bombers for strafing and bombing practice.

column1: Clearwater is located at 27°58′25″N 82°45′51″W.According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 39.2 square miles (101.6 km2)
column3: of which 25.6 square miles (66.2 km2) is land and 13.7 square miles (35.4 km2) (34.86%) is water.

column1: Clearwater's downtown has been undergoing major redevelopment in recent years. General beautification has been done along with completion of several high-rise condos and a large marina. The Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA) of Clearwater has played a major role in revitalizing housing of all income levels
column3: and attracting the interest of both public and private investors. New bars
column4: restaurants and other amenities are coming to the area
column5: renamed the "Cleveland Street District". Royalty Theatre is also slated to be renovated. Another feature is Coachman Park which hosts events throughout the year. The downtown core is approximately 2 miles (3 km) from Clearwater Beach and 6 miles (10 km) from downtown Dunedin. The drive to both places
column6: and many parts of downtown itself
column7: feature views of the water and the Clearwater Memorial Causeway.

column1: Clearwater has a humid subtropical climate. Clearwater is far enough south that it lies in the broad transition zone from subtropical to tropical climates. As such
column2: Clearwater is mostly warm to hot year round
column3: with few nights of frost. Most of the annual rainfall comes in the wet season (June through September)
column4: when daily thundershowers erupt due to the strong solar heating. The dry season starts in October and runs through May
column5: at which time the weather is sunny
column7: and there is little change in daily weather.

column1: Royalty Theater Company signed leases with the Taylor family in February 1981 when it then became known as the Royalty Theater (Clearwater
column2: Florida). The building was renovated with Ron Winter of Winter Associates as the contractor and Scott Musheff as the architect.During the renovations
column3: Bill Neville's murdered body was found in the balcony.The theatre remained in the Taylor family estate until it was sold in 1996. In July 2008 the building went into foreclosure.In January 2009
column4: the City of Clearwater and Ruth Eckerd Hall joined forces to purchase the theater (renamed Capitol Theater) as well as the neighboring Pat Lokey building.  They plan to renovate and revitalize the historic Capitol Theater.

column12: the Clearwater library increased its staff from three assistants to five assistants. The library's collection also grew from 18

column16: the Clearwater Public Library was for white patrons only from its founding in 1911 to the mid-twentieth century. In 1950

column24: the Clearwater Public Library System has become increasingly digital
column25: providing patrons with access to computers
column27: and an online library catalog. This was made possible by the Greater Clearwater Public Library Foundation
column28: Inc. which formed in 1984. As a part of the library's Centennial Celebration

The Main library's makerspace is the "Studio's at Main" and targets creative arts making.The Clearwater Public Library System is a contributor to the Pinellas Memory Project. This system of libraries is part of the Pinellas Public Library Cooperative which seeks to provide patrons with access to information and programs to benefit the community.

column1: The Clearwater Marine Aquarium is a small non-profit organization and aquarium. Opening in 1972 on Clearwater Beach
column2: the aquarium is most famous for Winter
column3: one of their resident dolphins. Winter was rescued as a calf in 2005 and is one of the first dolphins to have been fitted with a prosthetic tail. Winter lost her tail soon after being rescued due to severe injuries as a result of entanglement in a crab trap. The CMA has two other resident dolphins; Hope and Nicholas. Hope and Nicholas were both also rescued as calves
column4: though approximately eight years apart from each other. All three dolphins are permanent residents and are unable to be released due to concerns of how they would fare
column5: lacking major survival skills usually taught by a calf's mother. The aquarium is also home to otters
column8: and turtles among several species of fish and other marine life. CMA also assists in animal strandings and other emergencies regarding sea life. Animals that have stranded are rehabilitated
column10: released back into the wild once they have made a full recovery. It has been featured as the main setting of the American family movie series Dolphin Tale.

column1: Spectrum Field in Clearwater is the spring training home of Major League Baseball's Philadelphia Phillies
column2: as well as their High-A affiliate
column3: the Clearwater Threshers.

column1: Moccasin Lake Nature Park is a 51-acre nature preserve with a 5-acre lake that is owned and operated by the city. The preserve also features the Moccasin Lake Environmental Education Center
column3: programs and camps. The Center features live rehabilitated birds of prey
column4: reptiles
column5: amphibians and aquatic wildlife. It opened in 1982. The City of Clearwater contains five pools: Ross Norton
column9: and Clearwater Beach. Swim lessons are offered throughout the year to patrons
column10: and the pools have both a recreation summer pool league and the Clearwater Aquatics Team. These pools have participated in the World's Largest Swim Lesson.

column1: The City of Clearwater is administered by a council-manager form of government
column2: and the city manager serves as the chief executive and administrative officer of the city.The Clearwater City Council comprises the mayor and four council members
column3: each of whom serves a four-year term. The council is responsible for setting policies and making decisions on local government issues including tax rates
column4: annexations
column5: property code variances and large contract awards. The city manager and city council are supported by the various city departments.

column1: Tampa International Airport serves Clearwater and the rest of the Tampa Bay Area as the primary means of air travel. St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport has also seen its usage increase. The city owns Clearwater Air Park.
The Pinellas Suncoast Transit Authority (PSTA) bus service is currently Pinellas County's only general public transit.  The service offers approximately 35 local routes
column2: two express routes which cross Tampa Bay to the east
column3: and a beach trolley that runs north and south along the county's roughly 25-mile-long (40 km) chain of barrier islands.

column1: Beginning in the 1970s under the code-name Project Normandy
column2: the Church of Scientology began targeting Clearwater in order to "establish area control" of the city and county. The operations were exposed in a Pulitzer Prize winning series of articles in the Clearwater Sun.Gabe Cazares
column3: who was the mayor of Clearwater at the time
column4: went so far as to call it "the occupation of Clearwater" and later characterized it as a "paramilitary operation by a terrorist group". The Church of Scientology targeted Cazares
column5: attempting to entrap him in a sex scandal. Scientology also staged a phony hit-and-run accident with Cazares in an attempt to discredit him. Cazares and his wife sued the Church of Scientology for $1.5 million. The church settled with Cazares in 1986.The Church of Scientology's headquarters are located in downtown Clearwater. The Church refers to Clearwater as their "Flag Land Base".
